title: Judges Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Judges chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Judges Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Judges Chapter 21.

questions.question: What oath did the men of Israel swear in Mizpeh?
options: They would not give their daughters to Benjamin to wife
They would destroy the city of Shiloh
They would all fast for seven days
They would choose a king immediately
questions.correctAnswer: They would not give their daughters to Benjamin to wife
questions.explanation: Judges 21:1 states that the men of Israel swore in Mizpeh that none would give his daughter to Benjamin to wife.

questions.question: Where did the people of Israel go and stay before God, lifting up their voices and weeping?
options: The house of God
The rock Rimmon
The vineyards
The city of Jabeshgilead
questions.correctAnswer: The house of God
questions.explanation: Judges 21:2 says the people came to the house of God and abode there till evening, crying out and weeping before God.

questions.question: What did the Israelites ask God about in Judges 21:3?
options: Why one tribe was lacking in Israel
When the famine would end
Where the promised land was
Who would be their king
questions.correctAnswer: Why one tribe was lacking in Israel
questions.explanation: Judges 21:3 records the Israelites asking God why there should be one tribe lacking in Israel.

questions.question: What did the people do on the morrow after their prayer and weeping?
options: Built an altar and offered burnt and peace offerings
Sent men to spy on the children of Benjamin
Destroyed the vineyards of Shiloh
Appointed a new leader
questions.correctAnswer: Built an altar and offered burnt and peace offerings
questions.explanation: Judges 21:4 states that the people rose early, built an altar, and offered burnt and peace offerings.

questions.question: True or False: According to Judges 21:7, the Israelites were concerned how to give wives to the remaining Benjamites after swearing not to give their daughters to them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 21:7 shows the Israelites worrying about how to provide wives for the Benjamites since they had sworn not to give their daughters to them.

questions.question: Which tribe did not come up to the assembly at Mizpeh, prompting Israel to send men to attack them?
options: Jabeshgilead
Benjamin
Judah
Ephraim
questions.correctAnswer: Jabeshgilead
questions.explanation: Judges 21:8-9 states that no one from Jabeshgilead came to the assembly, so Israel sent men to attack them.

questions.question: How many men were sent to smite the inhabitants of Jabeshgilead?
options: Twelve thousand
Ten thousand
Five thousand
Twenty thousand
questions.correctAnswer: Twelve thousand
questions.explanation: Judges 21:10 says twelve thousand men of the valiantest were sent to smite Jabeshgilead.

questions.question: What was the command given about the women of Jabeshgilead who had lain with a man?
options: They were to be destroyed
They were to be spared
They were to be taken as concubines
They were to be made priests
questions.correctAnswer: They were to be destroyed
questions.explanation: Judges 21:11 commands that every male and every woman who had lain with a man should be destroyed.

questions.question: How many young virgins did the Israelites find among the inhabitants of Jabeshgilead?
options: Four hundred
One hundred
Two hundred
Five hundred
questions.correctAnswer: Four hundred
questions.explanation: Judges 21:12 states they found four hundred young virgins who had known no man.

questions.question: True or False: The Benjamites were given wives from the women of Jabeshgilead but still did not have enough wives.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 21:14 confirms that the Benjamites were given the women from Jabeshgilead, but it was not sufficient.

questions.question: What was the reason given why the children of Israel could not give their daughters to Benjamin as wives?
options: They had sworn an oath that cursed anyone who gave a wife to Benjamin
They did not have enough daughters
The daughters refused to marry Benjamin
Benjamin had no land
questions.correctAnswer: They had sworn an oath that cursed anyone who gave a wife to Benjamin
questions.explanation: Judges 21:18 explains they could not give daughters to Benjamin because of the oath which said, 'Cursed be he that giveth a wife to Benjamin.'

questions.question: Where was the feast of the LORD held yearly, where the daughters of Shiloh came out to dance?
options: North side of Bethel, east side of the highway from Bethel to Shechem
South side of Jerusalem
West side of the Jordan River
In the city of Jabeshgilead
questions.correctAnswer: North side of Bethel, east side of the highway from Bethel to Shechem
questions.explanation: Judges 21:19 describes the feast location as on the north side of Bethel, east side of the highway from Bethel to Shechem.

questions.question: What did the Benjamites do during the feast to obtain wives?
options: Lay in wait in the vineyards and took wives from the daughters of Shiloh as they danced
Asked the elders for wives from other tribes
Married the women of Jabeshgilead again
Built new cities to attract wives
questions.correctAnswer: Lay in wait in the vineyards and took wives from the daughters of Shiloh as they danced
questions.explanation: Judges 21:20-21 states the Benjamites lay in wait, caught the daughters of Shiloh dancing, and took them as wives.

questions.question: True or False: After receiving wives, the children of Benjamin repaired their cities and dwelt in them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 21:23 shows the children of Benjamin took wives, repaired their cities, and dwelt in them.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Judges 21:25: 'In those days there was no king in Israel: every man did that which was ______ in his own eyes.'
options: right
wrong
evil
wise
questions.correctAnswer: right
questions.explanation: Judges 21:25 states that every man did that which was right in his own eyes in those days.

questions.question: After the events in Judges 21, what did the children of Israel do?
options: They departed each to their tribe and family to their inheritance
They built a temple in Shiloh
They appointed a new king
They destroyed the vineyards of Shiloh
questions.correctAnswer: They departed each to their tribe and family to their inheritance
questions.explanation: Judges 21:24 says the children of Israel departed every man to his tribe and family, returning to their inheritance.

medium.title: Judges Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Judges Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Judges 21 teach us about the importance of prayer and repentance in times of crisis?
options: We should seek God earnestly and repent as a community
We must rely on our own strength and actions alone
Ignoring the problem will make it go away
Only individuals need to repent, not the whole community
questions.correctAnswer: We should seek God earnestly and repent as a community
questions.explanation: Judges 21:2-3 shows the people gathering before God, weeping and asking why there is a tribe lacking, demonstrating communal prayer and repentance. Verses 5-6 indicate their sorrow and repentance for Benjamin.

questions.question: What lesson about faithfulness to oaths and the consequences of rash vows can we learn from Judges 21?
options: Be cautious about making vows to God because they have serious consequences
Vows can be ignored if they cause inconvenience
Only leaders need to keep their vows
Vows are not important in difficult situations
questions.correctAnswer: Be cautious about making vows to God because they have serious consequences
questions.explanation: Judges 21:1 and 21:7-8 reveal the Israelites swore not to give their daughters to Benjamin, causing a dilemma. Their oath led to unintended hardship, teaching the importance of careful vow-making.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with forgiving others after a community conflict. What does Judges 21 show about reconciliation?
options: Efforts should be made to restore relationships even after serious offenses
Forgiveness is not necessary after deep conflict
Separation is the only solution to conflict
Revenge is justified for community wrongs
questions.correctAnswer: Efforts should be made to restore relationships even after serious offenses
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 describe peaceful attempts to bring Benjamin back and provide wives, reflecting the value of reconciliation and restoration despite past conflicts (Judges 21:13-14).

questions.question: How does Judges 21 illustrate the importance of community responsibility and mutual support?
options: The tribes took responsibility to provide wives for Benjamin to preserve the tribe
Each tribe should only care for itself
Individualism is more important than community
Ignoring the needs of others is acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: The tribes took responsibility to provide wives for Benjamin to preserve the tribe
questions.explanation: Verses 16-17 show elders seeking ways to provide wives for the Benjamin remnant to prevent the tribe's destruction, emphasizing community support and stewardship (Judges 21:16-17).

questions.question: What biblical truth about trusting God's sovereignty can be drawn from the events in Judges 21?
options: God allowed a breach in Israel, teaching trust despite difficulties
We can control all outcomes by our own plans
God does not intervene in human conflicts
Trials show God has abandoned His people
questions.correctAnswer: God allowed a breach in Israel, teaching trust despite difficulties
questions.explanation: Judges 21:15 acknowledges that the LORD had made a breach in the tribes, showing God's sovereign control even amid human failure and trials.

questions.question: How does Judges 21 demonstrate the importance of obedience to God’s commands alongside practical wisdom?
options: The people sought God's guidance and also acted wisely to preserve the tribe of Benjamin
Ignoring God's commands is acceptable if practical needs arise
Practical wisdom alone suffices without seeking God
Blind obedience without wisdom is best
questions.correctAnswer: The people sought God's guidance and also acted wisely to preserve the tribe of Benjamin
questions.explanation: The people prayed, repented, and then took measured steps such as attacking Jabeshgilead and arranging wives (Judges 21:4-12, 18-23), showing a balance of faith and practical action.

questions.question: True or False: The men of Israel gave their daughters to the Benjamites as wives immediately after the oath at Mizpeh.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 21:1 and 21:7 show the Israelites swore not to give their daughters to the Benjamites, causing a problem in providing wives for them.

questions.question: True or False: The tribe of Benjamin was completely destroyed according to Judges 21.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 17 and 23 explain efforts to preserve Benjamin by providing wives and rebuilding cities, so the tribe was not destroyed.

questions.question: A believer struggles with discouragement after experiencing community division. Based on Judges 21, what would you encourage them regarding restoration?
options: Restoration is possible through prayer, repentance, and wise action
Division means permanent separation
The community should be abandoned
Restoration depends only on human effort
questions.correctAnswer: Restoration is possible through prayer, repentance, and wise action
questions.explanation: The chapter shows the Israelites prayed, repented, and took strategic steps to restore the tribe of Benjamin (Judges 21:2-6, 18-23), teaching hope in restoration.

questions.question: What does Judges 21 teach about humility and contentment in difficult circumstances?
options: The people accepted their situation and sought humble solutions to preserve the tribe
They demanded more than was possible
They ignored their problem out of pride
They blamed others without taking responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: The people accepted their situation and sought humble solutions to preserve the tribe
questions.explanation: Verses 14-16 show the people repented and sought ways to help Benjamin despite difficulties, reflecting humility and contentment with God's providence.

questions.question: How does Judges 21 model the importance of church fellowship and serving others in times of crisis?
options: The tribes worked together to solve the problem of Benjamin’s wives
Each tribe acted selfishly and ignored others
Church fellowship is unnecessary in crisis
Only the tribe of Benjamin was concerned
questions.correctAnswer: The tribes worked together to solve the problem of Benjamin’s wives
questions.explanation: The entire congregation cooperated, sending men to Jabeshgilead and arranging for wives, demonstrating fellowship and mutual service (Judges 21:10-12, 19-23).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Judges 21:25 states, 'In those days there was no king in Israel: every man did that which was ______ in his own eyes.'
options: right
wrong
evil
pleasing
questions.correctAnswer: right
questions.explanation: Verse 25 clearly states that every man did that which was right in his own eyes, highlighting the lack of godly leadership and resulting disorder.

questions.question: What practical biblical wisdom regarding marriage and family life is demonstrated in Judges 21?
options: It is important to ensure marriages to preserve family and tribal continuity
Marriage is unimportant in community stability
Family ties should be broken to avoid conflict
Marriage arrangements should be made without consideration
questions.correctAnswer: It is important to ensure marriages to preserve family and tribal continuity
questions.explanation: The Israelites focused on providing wives for Benjamin to maintain the tribe (Judges 21:7, 17, 23), showing the value of marriage for family and community preservation.

questions.question: Based on Judges 21, how should believers handle the consequences of rash decisions or vows?
options: Seek God’s guidance, repent, and take responsible steps to remedy harm
Ignore the consequences and continue as before
Blame others without changing course
Refuse to make amends regardless of impact
questions.correctAnswer: Seek God’s guidance, repent, and take responsible steps to remedy harm
questions.explanation: The people prayed, repented, and took action to provide wives for Benjamin despite their oath (Judges 21:2-6, 18-23), illustrating responsible handling of consequences.

questions.question: How does Judges 21 encourage perseverance through trials and challenges?
options: The Israelites persevered to preserve Benjamin despite difficulties
They gave up when faced with obstacles
They blamed God for their problems
They avoided facing the issues
questions.correctAnswer: The Israelites persevered to preserve Benjamin despite difficulties
questions.explanation: Verses 14-23 detail the efforts and persistence of Israel to restore Benjamin’s tribe, showing perseverance through trials.

hard.title: Judges Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Judges Chapter 21.

questions.question: What was the oath that the men of Israel made at Mizpeh concerning the tribe of Benjamin?
options: They would not give their daughters as wives to Benjamin
They would offer sacrifices for Benjamin
They would protect Benjamin from enemies
They would share their land with Benjamin
questions.correctAnswer: They would not give their daughters as wives to Benjamin
questions.explanation: Judges 21:1 states that the men of Israel swore that none would give his daughter to Benjamin as a wife, which caused a crisis in the tribe.

questions.question: How did the people of Israel respond emotionally when they gathered at the house of God after the oath?
options: They lifted up their voices and wept sore
They celebrated with singing and dancing
They remained silent and fasted
They argued among themselves
questions.correctAnswer: They lifted up their voices and wept sore
questions.explanation: Judges 21:2 describes the people weeping sore before God, showing their deep sorrow for what had happened to the tribe of Benjamin.

questions.question: In Judges 21:3, the people ask God why there should be one tribe lacking in Israel. This reflects which biblical theme?
options: The unity and wholeness of Israel as God's chosen people
The necessity of warfare for survival
The importance of individual tribal autonomy
The rejection of God's covenant
questions.correctAnswer: The unity and wholeness of Israel as God's chosen people
questions.explanation: The question in Judges 21:3 reveals the concern for the completeness of Israel, emphasizing the theological theme of the unity of God's people.

questions.question: What action did the Israelites take the day after they wept before God, according to Judges 21:4?
options: They built an altar and offered burnt and peace offerings
They sent spies to Benjamin's territory
They renewed their oath against Benjamin
They fasted and prayed all day
questions.correctAnswer: They built an altar and offered burnt and peace offerings
questions.explanation: Judges 21:4 shows the Israelites’ act of worship and seeking reconciliation through sacrifices after their lamentation.

questions.question: According to Judges 21:10-11, what specific command was given to the twelve thousand men sent to Jabeshgilead?
options: To utterly destroy every male and every woman who had lain with a man
To make peace treaties with the inhabitants
To take prisoners for ransom
To build a new altar in Jabeshgilead
questions.correctAnswer: To utterly destroy every male and every woman who had lain with a man
questions.explanation: Verses 10 and 11 instruct the men to kill all males and the women who were not virgins, sparing only virgins, highlighting a harsh wartime measure.

questions.question: How many young virgins were found among the inhabitants of Jabeshgilead, as recorded in Judges 21:12?
options: Four hundred
One thousand
Two hundred
Three hundred
questions.correctAnswer: Four hundred
questions.explanation: Judges 21:12 states that four hundred young virgins were found, and these were spared to be given as wives to the Benjaminite men.

questions.question: What was the significance of the feast in Shiloh mentioned in Judges 21:19 in the context of the narrative?
options: It provided an opportunity for Benjaminite men to capture wives
It was a feast to mourn the loss of the tribe
It marked the renewal of the covenant
It was a celebration of military victory
questions.correctAnswer: It provided an opportunity for Benjaminite men to capture wives
questions.explanation: Judges 21:19 describes the feast as a setting where Benjaminite men could find wives among the dancing daughters, circumventing the oath.

questions.question: In Judges 21:21, what strategy did the Benjaminite men use to obtain wives during the feast?
options: They hid in vineyards and captured the daughters of Shiloh as they danced
They asked the daughters directly for marriage
They negotiated with other tribes
They arranged a formal betrothal ceremony
questions.correctAnswer: They hid in vineyards and captured the daughters of Shiloh as they danced
questions.explanation: The men lay in wait and seized wives during the dance, as described in Judges 21:21, which reflects a cultural practice of the time to resolve the crisis.

questions.question: What reason did the Israelites plan to give if the fathers or brothers of the daughters complained about the captures, according to Judges 21:22?
options: They would ask for favor for their sake, explaining the wives were not given in war
They would admit to wrongdoing and offer compensation
They would deny the captures
They would declare a new war
questions.correctAnswer: They would ask for favor for their sake, explaining the wives were not given in war
questions.explanation: Judges 21:22 explains the planned reasoning to avoid guilt by stating the wives were reserved because they were not given during the war, seeking mercy.

questions.question: True or False: The elders of Israel allowed giving daughters as wives to Benjamin without any restrictions to solve the problem of the missing tribe.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 21:7 and 21:18 indicate that the Israelites had sworn not to give their daughters to Benjamin, so they sought alternative solutions.

questions.question: What does Judges 21:25 reveal about the leadership and moral state of Israel at this time?
options: There was no king, and everyone did what was right in their own eyes
Israel was united under a strong king
The priests were the sole leaders
The nation was ruled by judges with absolute authority
questions.correctAnswer: There was no king, and everyone did what was right in their own eyes
questions.explanation: This verse summarizes the period's anarchy and moral relativism, emphasizing the lack of centralized authority.

questions.question: Why did the Israelites send 12,000 men to attack Jabeshgilead, according to Judges 21:8-10?
options: Because Jabeshgilead had not come to the assembly at Mizpeh
Because Jabeshgilead had attacked Benjamin
Because Jabeshgilead refused to worship God
Because Jabeshgilead had allied with Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: Because Jabeshgilead had not come to the assembly at Mizpeh
questions.explanation: Verses 8-9 clearly state that Jabeshgilead's inhabitants did not appear at Mizpeh, violating the communal oath, prompting the attack.

questions.question: How does the episode in Judges 21 emphasize the theme of covenant and oath in Israelite society?
options: It shows the serious consequences of breaking or swearing oaths
It shows that oaths can be easily ignored
It suggests that oaths were not important to the Israelites
It demonstrates the superiority of tribal autonomy over national unity
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the serious consequences of breaking or swearing oaths
questions.explanation: The narrative centers around the consequences of the oath at Mizpeh and the lengths taken to uphold or work around it, highlighting its gravity.

questions.question: Which cultural practice is illustrated by the Benjaminite men capturing wives during a festival dance, as seen in Judges 21:21?
options: Marriage by abduction as a socially accepted custom in times of crisis
Peaceful arranged marriages between tribes
Public betrothal ceremonies in the tabernacle
Tribute marriages to foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: Marriage by abduction as a socially accepted custom in times of crisis
questions.explanation: The capture of wives during the dance reflects an ancient Near Eastern custom to resolve a demographic crisis, as in Judges 21:21.

questions.question: How does the final verse, Judges 21:25, function as a literary conclusion to the Book of Judges?
options: It summarizes the chaotic moral and political state without a centralized king
It proclaims the establishment of monarchy
It promises future restoration through a prophet
It recounts the final victory over enemies
questions.correctAnswer: It summarizes the chaotic moral and political state without a centralized king
questions.explanation: Verse 25 encapsulates the recurring theme of Judges—lack of leadership and moral confusion before the monarchy.

theological.title: Judges Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Judges Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What did the men of Israel swear at Mizpeh regarding the tribe of Benjamin?
options: They would not give their daughters to Benjamin as wives
They would support Benjamin in battle
They would share their land with Benjamin
They would lead Benjamin in worship
questions.correctAnswer: They would not give their daughters to Benjamin as wives
questions.explanation: Judges 21:1 records that the men of Israel swore that none would give their daughters to Benjamin as wives. This shows a severe covenant oath impacting the tribe's future. Similar serious covenants appear in biblical history (Genesis 21:23-24; 1 Samuel 20:42; Psalm 15:4) emphasizing the weight of oaths before God.

questions.question: What was the people's response when they came to the house of God after the oath regarding Benjamin?
options: They wept sore and lifted up their voices
They rejoiced and sang praises
They remained silent and bowed
They argued about the oath
questions.correctAnswer: They wept sore and lifted up their voices
questions.explanation: Judges 21:2 describes the people weeping sore and lifting their voices before God, showing repentance and sorrow for the consequences of their oath. This parallels the penitential cries in Psalms (Psalm 6:6; Joel 2:12-13; Nehemiah 1:4) where the people express lament before God.

questions.question: What was the reason given by the people for their lamentation about the tribe of Benjamin?
options: One tribe was lacking in Israel
Benjamin had committed idolatry
Benjamin had attacked Israel
Benjamin had no land
questions.correctAnswer: One tribe was lacking in Israel
questions.explanation: In Judges 21:3, the people question why one tribe is lacking in Israel, showing concern for the unity and completeness of God’s covenant people. This reflects the biblical theme of God's people being one (Deuteronomy 32:8; Ezekiel 37:22; Romans 11:17-24).

questions.question: What did the people do on the morrow after their lamentation?
options: Built an altar and offered burnt and peace offerings
Sent messengers to Benjamin
Destroyed idols in the land
Fasted and prayed silently
questions.correctAnswer: Built an altar and offered burnt and peace offerings
questions.explanation: Judges 21:4 records that the people rose early and built an altar to offer burnt and peace offerings, demonstrating a return to covenant worship and seeking God's favor. This act echoes the sacrificial system's role in atonement and restoration (Leviticus 1:3-4; Exodus 20:24; Hebrews 10:1-10).

questions.question: What was the punishment decreed for those who did not come up to the LORD at Mizpeh?
options: They shall surely be put to death
They shall be exiled
They shall be fined
They shall be forgiven after repentance
questions.correctAnswer: They shall surely be put to death
questions.explanation: Judges 21:5 states that those who did not come up to the LORD at Mizpeh were to be put to death, illustrating the seriousness of covenant obedience. This reflects God's covenant demands seen throughout Scripture (Deuteronomy 13:12-17; Numbers 15:30-31; Hebrews 10:26-31).

questions.question: How did the Israelites feel about Benjamin after enforcing the oath?
options: They repented for Benjamin their brother
They rejoiced over their victory
They ignored Benjamin
They sought to destroy Benjamin completely
questions.correctAnswer: They repented for Benjamin their brother
questions.explanation: Judges 21:6 shows that the Israelites repented for Benjamin, recognizing him as their brother and feeling sorrow over the tribe being cut off. This highlights the biblical principle of corporate responsibility and unity (Psalm 133:1; Ephesians 4:1-6; 1 Corinthians 12:12-27).

questions.question: What solution did the elders propose for providing wives to the remaining men of Benjamin without breaking the oath?
options: To find wives from the women of Shiloh during a feast
To break the oath and give their daughters
To allow Benjamin men to marry outside Israel
To adopt daughters from other tribes
questions.correctAnswer: To find wives from the women of Shiloh during a feast
questions.explanation: Judges 21:19-21 explains that the elders advised the men of Benjamin to capture wives from the daughters of Shiloh during a feast, thus not breaking the oath. This unusual solution reflects the tension between covenant keeping and the preservation of a tribe, echoing God's providence in difficult circumstances (Genesis 24:3-4; Exodus 22:16-17; Romans 8:28).

questions.question: Who were the four hundred virgins taken from in order to provide wives for Benjamin?
options: The inhabitants of Jabeshgilead
The daughters of Shiloh
The daughters of Bethel
The women of Shechem
questions.correctAnswer: The inhabitants of Jabeshgilead
questions.explanation: Judges 21:12 states that four hundred virgins were taken from Jabeshgilead, who had not known a man. This act was to preserve Benjamin from extinction, showing God's mercy working through human decisions despite the imperfect circumstances (Genesis 34; Exodus 22:16-17; Ruth 4:13).

questions.question: What was the condition for the people of Jabeshgilead before the four hundred virgins were taken?
options: Every male and every woman who had lain with a man was to be destroyed
They were to be given peace offerings
They were to join the tribe of Benjamin
They were to be exiled from Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Every male and every woman who had lain with a man was to be destroyed
questions.explanation: Judges 21:11 records that all males and any woman who had lain with a man were to be utterly destroyed, sparing only the virgins. This reflects the harsh justice seen in the Old Testament for covenant purity (Deuteronomy 13:12-16; Numbers 31:17-18; Joshua 6:21).

questions.question: What was the people's attitude toward the breach in the tribes of Israel caused by the oath?
options: They repented for Benjamin because the LORD had made a breach
They justified the oath as righteous
They ignored the breach and moved on
They blamed Benjamin for the breach
questions.correctAnswer: They repented for Benjamin because the LORD had made a breach
questions.explanation: In Judges 21:15, the people repented for Benjamin, acknowledging that the LORD had caused the breach among the tribes. This shows recognition of God's sovereignty even in judgment and division (2 Samuel 12:13-14; Psalm 51:1-4; Jonah 3:9-10).

questions.question: Why could the Israelites not give their daughters to the men of Benjamin despite the need for wives?
options: Because they had sworn a curse against giving wives to Benjamin
Because Benjamin was unclean
Because Benjamin had no land to give daughters
Because the daughters refused to marry Benjamin
questions.correctAnswer: Because they had sworn a curse against giving wives to Benjamin
questions.explanation: Judges 21:18 clarifies that the Israelites could not give their daughters because of the oath, which invoked a curse on anyone who did. This highlights the binding nature of vows before God (Ecclesiastes 5:4-5; Numbers 30:2; Matthew 5:33-37).

questions.question: Where was the feast held where the daughters danced, allowing Benjamin to find wives?
options: In Shiloh, on the north side of Bethel
In Jerusalem, near the temple
In Hebron, near the cave of Machpelah
In Gilgal, by the Jordan river
questions.correctAnswer: In Shiloh, on the north side of Bethel
questions.explanation: Judges 21:19 describes the feast of the LORD in Shiloh, located north of Bethel, where the daughters danced. Shiloh was a religious center before the temple, emphasizing the connection between worship and community life (Joshua 18:1; 1 Samuel 1:3; Psalm 78:60).

questions.question: What did the children of Benjamin do after taking wives from the daughters of Shiloh?
options: They returned to their inheritance and repaired their cities
They were cursed and exiled
They refused to dwell among the other tribes
They abandoned their land
questions.correctAnswer: They returned to their inheritance and repaired their cities
questions.explanation: Judges 21:23 records that Benjamin took wives, returned to their land, repaired their cities, and dwelt there. This restoration reflects God's providential preservation of His people despite human failures (Nehemiah 2:17-18; Ezra 4:1-5; Isaiah 58:12).

questions.question: What does Judges 21:25 say about the leadership and moral state of Israel during this time?
options: There was no king, and everyone did what was right in their own eyes
There was a strong king leading Israel
The priests ruled with complete authority
The people followed the law strictly
questions.correctAnswer: There was no king, and everyone did what was right in their own eyes
questions.explanation: Judges 21:25 states that there was no king in Israel and everyone did what was right in their own eyes, indicating moral and political chaos. This sets the stage for the demand for monarchy in 1 Samuel 8, illustrating the human need for godly leadership (Proverbs 29:18; Romans 3:10-18; Jeremiah 17:9).

questions.question: What theological principle can be drawn from the Israelites' repentance for the tribe of Benjamin after the oath?
options: God's covenant people are bound together as one body
Curses are irreversible and final
Oaths to God can be ignored if inconvenient
Individual tribes act independently without consequences
questions.correctAnswer: God's covenant people are bound together as one body
questions.explanation: The repentance for Benjamin in Judges 21:6,15 highlights the unity of God's people as one body, bearing each other's burdens (Romans 12:4-5; 1 Corinthians 12:12-27; Galatians 6:2). This unity is central to biblical ecclesiology and the covenant community.

questions.question: How does the episode of Benjamin in Judges 21 illustrate the balance between justice and mercy in God's dealings with His people?
options: The people enforce justice through the oath but show mercy by providing wives
Justice is ignored in favor of mercy
Mercy is denied to Benjamin completely
Justice is absolute without any mercy
questions.correctAnswer: The people enforce justice through the oath but show mercy by providing wives
questions.explanation: The chapter shows that while the Israelites uphold justice by enforcing the oath (Judges 21:1,5), they also show mercy by finding wives for Benjamin to preserve the tribe (Judges 21:12,19-21). This tension reflects God's character revealed in Scriptures like Micah 6:8, Psalm 85:10, and the mercy shown through Christ (Ephesians 2:4-5).
